sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-5 feet tall) or Small (about 3-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Biomimicry
entries: You can also use your action to touch a creature and assume its general form. Your size and other statistics don't change. If the target has a Burrow speed, Climb speed, or Swim speed, you gain that speed, up to a maximum of 40 feet.

Your transformation lasts for 1 hour or until you dismiss it (no action required). If you transform into a form incapable of wearing clothing or armor, your clothing or armor falls off. Your ability to handle objects is determined by the form's limbs rather than your own.

entries.name: Flexible Form
entries: You can use your action to stretch, compress, and mold your body into a myriad of shapes. You can shape-shift into any static form that you choose that is no larger than 8 feet in any dimension. When you assume this form, you can replicate something's basic shape but not its color, texture, moving parts, or fine details. You can't change your body's volume, nor can you move, attack, or cast spells while you're shape-shifted into a static shape.

entries.name: Reform
entries: Whenever you take Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage from an attack and don't drop to 0 hit points, you take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to immediately regain {@dice 1d4} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, up to a maximum of the amount of damage taken.
This healing increases to {@dice 1d6} at 5th level, {@dice 1d8} at 11th level, and {@dice 1d10} at 17th level.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Avian Eyes
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Perception|XPHB} skill. Additionally, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Blessings of the Sun
entries: You know the {@spell Light|XPHB} cantrip. When you reach character level 3, you learn the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell, and when you reach character level 5, you learn the {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} spell. You always have these spells prepared. You can cast each of these spells once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast the spell in that way again when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells when you cast them with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Zealous
entries: When you fail an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to roll a {@dice d4} and add it to the save, potentially turning the failure into a success.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 7-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe underwater. However, without your Aqua Suit, breathing air is uncomfortable for you, feeling similar to a human in very thin air.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any saving throw you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition. You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

entries.name: Aqua Suit
entries: Except when you are aboard a whorl ship, you wear a bulky Aqua Suit, which is filled with Poseidon Solution, in order to breathe comfortably. The suit covers your whole body, including a large domed helmet that allows you to see without hindrance.

You can don or doff the helmet on your turn (no action required), and you can don or doff the entire suit in 1 minute. If damaged but not completely destroyed, the suit rapidly mends itself, leaking a minimum amount of water. While wearing the suit, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Armored Suit
entries: Your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} equals 13 plus your Dexterity modifier. You can fit armor around your Aqua Suit and wear both simultaneously, using either armor to determine your AC. You can use a {@item Shield|XPHB} and still gain this benefit.

entries.name: Fire Resistance
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Fire damage.

entries.name: Life Suit
entries: You gain the benefits of wearing a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}.

entries.name: Universal Translator
entries: You can use the suit's embedded {@item Universal Translator|DarkMatter24} magic item at will.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 6-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Follow Through
entries: When you roll damage for a melee attack you make using a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can reroll the damage dice and deal an extra {@damage 1d4} damage to the target. You must use the new roll.
You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Gearhead
entries: Building sick rides is practically an orc pastime. You have proficiency with {@item Ship Maintenance Tools|DarkMatter24} and {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any check you make to repair or modify a ship. Additionally, you have proficiency in the {@skill Athletics|XPHB}, {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Piloting|DarkMatter24}, or {@skill Technology|DarkMatter24} skill.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any saving throw you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition. You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 6-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Adaptive Metabolism
entries: Your body can quickly adapt to a range of extreme environments. You take no damage from the extreme temperatures of space and other harsh environments (see [Appendix E]), and you can hold your breath for up to 15 minutes.

entries.name: Gliding Wings
entries: You have a pair of membranous wings that you can use to glide clumsily through the air. While falling, you can move up to 10 feet horizontally for every 5 feet you fall, up to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. Additionally, you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to damage you take as a result of falling.

entries.name: Hooked Claws
entries: Your digits end in short claws that you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}. You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}. When you deal damage with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can deal Slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} plus your Strength or Dexterity modifier instead of the strike's normal damage.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have an armored carapace. While you aren't wearing armor, your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} equals 13 plus your Dexterity modifier. You can use a {@item Shield|XPHB} and still gain this benefit.

entries.name: Regenerative
entries: If any part of your body is amputated, but its amputation doesn't kill you, that body part fully regrows over the course of 24 hours.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Construct Anatomy
entries: You don't need food, drink, or air. You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep. You can finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in 4 hours if you spend those hours in a motionless state, during which you retain consciousness.

entries.name: Inflexible Mind
entries: Your mechanical mind is inherently logical and not easily swayed. You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition on yourself.

entries.name: Reconfigurable Ability Scores
entries: When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can swap two of your ability scores. This change lasts until you use this feature again.

entries.name: Thermalsight
entries: You gain {@sense Thermalsight|DarkMatter24} with a range of 30 feet. (See the Glossary.)

entries.name: Construct Grafts
entries: You can take the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to install a construct graft on your body. Additionally, you don't suffer any ill effects from attaching a graft in a body slot for the first time, and it takes you no time to recover after the attachment of a new graft. See [Chapter X] for construct grafts.
You have the following graft installed in the External slot:

entries.name: Embedded Armor
entries: Your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} equals 13 plus your Dexterity modifier. You can wear armor on top of your Embedded Armor, and you can use either armor to determine your AC. You can use a {@item Shield|XPHB} and still gain this benefit.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Psionic Blast
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with a burst of psionic energy against a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 1d10} Psychic damage, or half as much damage on a successful save. This damage increases by {@dice 1d10} when you reach character levels 5 ({@dice 2d10}), 11 ({@dice 3d10}), and 17 ({@dice 4d10}).
You can use this blast a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Psychic Resistance
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

entries.name: Razor Claws
entries: You can use your teeth and claws to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}. You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}. When you deal damage with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can deal Slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} plus your Strength or Dexterity modifier instead of the strike's normal damage.

entries.name: Telepathy
entries: You can speak telepathically to any creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself. Your telepathic utterances are in a language you know, and the creature understands you only if it knows that language. Your communication doesn't give the creature the ability to respond to you telepathically.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall) or Small (about 2-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Resourceful
entries: You gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Skillful
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

entries.name: Near-Human Feat
entries: You gain a {@filter Near-Human Origin feat|feats|source=darkmatter24|other=race} of your choice.

raceFluff.name: Amoeboid

entries: Another failed experiment, muttered Yr. The amoeboid's nucleus flashed dark red with resigned frustration as a pair of automatons scraped viscera off the walls and ceiling of his medical bay.

The serum made no difference—those cows were just like the last batch, grumbled Yr. He made his way to the next room, where a terrified human lay restrained on a table, yelling incoherently. Yr tapped the man on the shoulder with a blobby appendage, setting off a ripple of changes through the amoeboid's body, settling into the vague shape of a human with an overlarge head and bulging eyes.

Sorry for the inconvenience, Yr apologized in the man's language. “I wish I could repay you for your livestock, but we have rules against that sort of thing. Now please stop squirming while I prepare a memory modification.
entries.by: Yr, amoeboid scientist, assessing a Void experiment

entries: Amoeboids are intelligent, vaguely humanoid-shaped oozes that can mimic the form of any creature they touch. These beings dwell on maw stations, experimenting at the cutting edge of science and parlaying with any creature they encounter.

entries.name: Fluid Anatomy
entries: Amoeboid bodies are composed of a translucent jelly-like substance with a complex network of nerves visible throughout, emitting a dim light. They range in color from blues and purples to bubblegum pink, with scintillating rainbows in between. Within an amoeboid's head floats a large, brain-like nucleus surrounded by five radially-spaced eyespots—their unearthly equivalent of a face.

An amoeboid can take a genetic imprint of a creature they touch, molding into an inexact copy, visibly made of the same jelly material. When in this form, they can speak the language of their subject and move in much the same way, allowing them to empathize with virtually any creature.

entries.name: Mawkeepers
entries: Amoeboids originate on the maw stations and most reside there, researching the stations' ancient technology, repairing ships and Dark Matter engines, and meeting people from across the 'Verse. By default, their position is that of galactic ambassadors, a role in which many amoeboids relish. They tend to regard newcomers with curiosity and enthusiasm, a disposition that has transformed their maw stations into central meeting places across the 'Verse.

entries.name: Scientists and Visitors
entries: Most amoeboids view the 'Verse through a lens of science and reason. With proper experimentation, the multiverse can be defined solely through the workings of magic and physics. Amoeboid researchers regard no subject as taboo as long as its methodology is sound and likely to produce useful data.

For centuries, amoeboids have taken to secretly visiting undeveloped worlds, disguising themselves and their saucers to experiment upon the inhabitants. These experiments are usually noninvasive but nonetheless unwelcome. As a result, many worlds share tales of strange visitors from the stars, looking much like them, but strangely distorted, stealing away individuals by night and performing strange rituals in brightly lit rooms. Amoeboids will also vivisect the odd head of livestock, but these occurrences are more likely to be blamed on predators than on visitors from the stars.

entries.name: Amoeboid Names
entries: Ever concerned with efficiency, amoeboid names can traditionally be represented by a single unusual character, to differentiate it from the rest of a particular alphabet. Amoeboids don't differentiate between males and females, nor are their names particularly masculine or feminine.

entries.name: Amoeboid Names
entries: Ash (Æ), Chevron (Λ), Digamma (Ͷ), Eth (Ð), Ezh (Ʒ), Gangia (Ϫ), Kai (ϗ), Pilcrow (¶), Psi (Ψ), Shei (Ϣ), Solidus (/), Thorn (Þ), Tilde (~), Yr (ᛦ)

raceFluff.name: Avia-Ra

entries: The center of the High Solarium bore a dazzling arrangement of polished bronze and glass lenses, flickering from one streak of light at the tip of the pyramid. As we lingered, captivated by the chamber's glow, our guide, the raven-headed Remembrancer Mose, stepped into the solarium's centermost platform. At once, the rays that cascaded throughout the solarium met their terminus, alighting her from every angle in a blinding radiance. A trick of the light, to be sure, but one that could have fooled us into believing everything she claimed: that the Sun Above itself spoke to her and delivered a prophecy.
entries.by: Jethro Meddlit, visiting the High Solarium of the avia-ra

entries: The avia-ra are a sun-worshiping race of wingless bird-people who travel to Low Worlds to spread their ancient religion.

entries.name: Ancient God-Kings
entries: Depictions of the avia-ra can be found in the ruins of ancient cultures throughout the galaxy. Often, but not always, they are portrayed as divinity manifest: godlike travelers from the heavens. Avia-Ra travel to more undeveloped worlds as evangelists of their solar religion—the Sun Above—and remain long enough to build an enduring civilization in their wake.

Some species consider the avia-ra an ancient and wise people, committed to the tenets of their religion. Others cast them as charlatans and false prophets, who routinely prey upon low worlds and defenseless peoples. The truth depends largely on perspective, but the avia-ra themselves aren't a monolith. Many have forsaken their faith or live agnostically, and the rest pledge varying devotion to the Sun Above.

entries.name: Watchers of the Citadel
entries: The heart of the avia-ra's religion is the Solar Citadel, which revolves close around the Sepulcher Star at the center of the galaxy. Most avia-ra make pilgrimage to this site at least once in their lives to bask in their holy sun, which (in their philosophy) gives light and meaning to all other stars. This worship is always directed at the Sepulcher Star itself, even if they are nearer to another star or no star at all. All other stars merely act as a metaphor, a symbol, of their holy sun.

In contrast to their binary doctrines, their actual relationship to the star and the Sepulcher within it is more complicated. The Solar Citadel definitively ensures that the star remains under avia-ra control, but the being within the star—Old Un—has never spoken to the avia-ra directly. Despite the silence, the avia-ra continue to pray in reverence and make pilgrimage to the Sepulcher Star.

entries.name: Deep Symbolism
entries: Avia-Ra are inclined to view the events around them as omens of larger struggles between light and dark, good and evil, and law and chaos. All things have symbolic importance and a place in the grand allegory, even fundamentally objective things like science and mathematics.

Most avia-ra hold dreams in especially high regard, for interpreted dreams can tell the future, lend insight into the past, or provide guidance for the present. Those with the gift to interpret dreams are honored as priests in the avia-ra and given elaborate titles, such as Grand Remembrancer or Dream-Teller Most High.

entries.name: Avia-Ra Names
entries: Avia-Ra names come in two-part cartouches, with one or both parts of the name being composed of the names of ancient avia-ra heroes and great ideals.

entries.name: Front Cartouche
entries: Anubis, Apophis, Cani, Canopis, Helio, Horus, Ira, Isis, Nefer, Oculus, Terra, Verum Rear Cartouche. Amet, Bast, Haten, Hotep, Intef, Lux, Ma'at, Mose, Omet, Osiris, Ptah, Set, Thoth

entries.name: Front Cartouche
entries: Anubis, Apophis, Cani, Canopis, Helio, Horus, Ira, Isis, Nefer, Oculus, Terra, Verum Rear Cartouche. Amet, Bast, Haten, Hotep, Intef, Lux, Ma'at, Mose, Omet, Osiris, Ptah, Set, Thoth

raceFluff.name: Nautild

entries: His heavy footfalls shook the deck as he stomped up from engineering—Titus Octavius didn't like being called up to the bridge. When he arrived, the captains were shouting over one another in different languages over the comms. It was a furious, incomprehensible tangle of Avia-Ra, Gnomish, and Elvish, with an undiplomatic number of rude gestures thrown in for good measure. Titus bellowed over the three of them: his colossal voice booming out of his Aqua Suit, first in Common, then in each of their languages. He translated tactfully and an agreement was shortly reached, but everyone knew that the captains acquiesced because none of them wanted to cross the towering nautilid again.
entries.by: Sgt. Larren, recounting his nautilid engineer

entries: A species of universe-spanning travelers, the hulking, fishlike nautilids patrol space in their massive whorl ships, exploring and cataloging any planet with enough water to sustain a colony. Few ever see these creatures' true forms, for they are most often concealed in imposing suits that look more like antique diving gear than sophisticated survival apparatuses.

entries.name: Orphaned Species
entries: Though the nautilids are among the oldest species in the 'Verse, they are fast dying out. Long after the nautilids discovered Dark Matter technology and started traversing the universe, disaster struck their homeworld, Poseidon, a vast planet of endless ocean. Their star began to swell, first heating the atmosphere, then boiling the oceans away. Within a few short decades, a supernova claimed the planet, leaving only scattered colonies and immense nautilid colony ships.

Without their homeworld, the nautilids are an orphaned species, growing up on small colonies and inside massive water-filled ships called whorls, which travel the universe. Their numbers dwindle with each decade, and if nothing changes, the next few centuries might see the end of the nautilids altogether.

entries.name: Endless Odyssey
entries: Ingenious and indefatigable, the nautilids search tirelessly, jumping from planet to planet in pursuit of a new homeworld. The oceans of Poseidon had a very specific aquatic composition of rare elements and dissolved gasses known as the Poseidon Solution. Though nautilids can live in both air and water, they do so uncomfortably, and can only relax (and produce offspring) in a similar solution.

So far, naturally-occuring Poseidon Solution hasn't been found in any planet's ocean, so it must be artificially reproduced to fill the nautilids' whorl ships and Aqua Suits. Finding oceans in the 'Verse is rare enough, but finding a suitable replacement for Poseidon has been a centuries-long challenge for the entire nautilid species.

entries.name: Nautilid Names
entries: By ancient tradition, nautilids are named in the old languages of Poseidon, and the second half of a nautilid's name is a surname passed down the maternal line. The meaning of most of these names have been lost to history, much like Poseidon itself.

entries.name: Nautilid Names
entries: Agrias, Charax, Democedes, Gorgias, Helenos, Idomeneus, Isokrates, Lysandros, Monomachus, Panthous, Theomestros, Xenagoras

raceFluff.name: Orc

entries: Once the rig was loaded on the lift, Dame're could slide underneath and start loosening the bolts that held the hull together. And just like that, the proud, pinstriped hot rod of a ship was unveiled for what it really was: cogs, pistons, gears, and belts, to say nothing of the grease. She smiled. This was more honest, and more accepting of the work. With a few more tune-ups, it'd be the fastest rig in the quadrant, maybe in the 'Verse.
entries.by: Dame're Krath, orc mechanic, modifying her ram rod

entries: Orcs are down-to-earth humanoids with green skin and imposing builds. Despite their reputation, few species in the 'Verse are quite as good with a wrench or as quick with a comeback.

entries.name: Pragmatic
entries: Orcs tend to be practical, common sense folks, who believe the best solution to a problem is one that works. Fixing machines and fiddling with hardware comes naturally to them, partially because an orcish preteen can lift an engine block, and partially because they find something satisfying in tools that have a purpose and machines that work well.

Most orc technology has developed according to the, "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" mindset, which has led to some truly unique designs. Their ships, which they call "rigs" or "rides," are powered by gasoline, and feature impressive exhaust pipes and air intakes. It's not uncommon to see one painted with pinstripes, flames, or entire murals. Likewise, their blasters still retain the trappings of ammunition-based guns, with magazines and prominent muzzles.

Many orcs take great pride in a well-oiled, finely tuned rig, especially if they've built it themselves. If an orc mechanic isn't fiddling with the engine of their rig until it hums, they're polishing the chassis or detailing the interior. The end result is a thing of beauty: a ship that is equal parts classic style and extraordinary engineering.

entries.name: Aftermath of War
entries: While history remembers the Warzone as being the consequence of a great orcish war, modern orcs remember almost nothing about the conflict. Their old national identities, on which the war originally centered, have been washed away with centuries of arcane warheads and goblinoid alliances, and those few which can escape the Warzone would rather pretend it didn't happen. They carry their history and culture with them, and feel a pang for the war that took their homeworld, but claim little responsibility for the violence of the Warzone today.

Orcs of the 'Verse have undergone a diaspora. A surprising number have ended up in the Dwarven Conclave as full citizens, and nearly as many have taken up residence in Lakshay. These orcs outside the Warzone usually claim the nationalities of their adopted homes, and are welcomed in kind. Inside the Warzone, however, orcs live among hobgoblin warchiefs which would conscript them into battle, and gnoll marauders which would raid their homes. As such, their life is a migratory one, whether fleeing the violence or pursuing it.

entries.name: Orc Names
entries: Many orcs have names derived from the hard consonants of their ancestral language, but many more adopt names from other species. It's rare, however, to see an orc with a particularly elaborate or ostentatious name.

entries.name: Male Orc Names
entries: Grax, Midor, Oliggon, Renk, Sared, Throg, Vrok

entries.name: Female Orc Names
entries: Atattica, Brabat, Elonar, Gula, Krenchu, Moza, Olim, Yorma

raceFluff.name: Skathári

entries: Gid'down!” I shouted and pulled Mor'rak, the new Skathári hire, behind a concrete barrier, just as a concussion grenade cracked in a wave of force.

Suddenly, it was all a hail of blaster fire: Coalition troops had finally tracked us, and decided to take us in dead, rather than alive. I retorted with my standard carbine, blasting off a few of them as they peeked from cover.

I drew my repeater and slid it over to Mor'rak. Bolts of white-hot plasma whizzing overhead, he stared blankly at the blaster for a moment, one of his mandibles quivering a bit. I leaned carefully over to Mor'rak, took his hand, opened his palm, and placed the repeater in it. He politely placed the repeater exactly where it had been on the floor.

While many spacers regard Tier 3 and 4 worlds as hostile, dangerous environments, skathári can think of no better place to call home. Hailing from the distant, mountainous world of Kopriá, whose seasons can last for years and whose volcanoes choke entire regions with sulfur gas, these insectoid creatures are perfectly adapted to life on harsh planets.

entries.name: Hardy Insectoids
entries: Standing upright between 6 and 7 feet tall, the hulking skathári only vaguely resemble humanoids. They have six limbs—four legs and two arms—each of them thin, lined with spines, and ending in a quartet of small hooked claws, suitable for deterring predators or climbing sheer cliff faces. Their chitinous shells range in color  from jet black, to speckled yellow, to a scintillating emerald green. Folded beneath the shells on their backs, they conceal a pair of broad, membranous wings, used to glide short distances. Some skathári have stronger wings that allow them short bursts of flight, but most are too heavy to remain airborne for long. A skathári's face appears small, framed by its hunched shell. Compound eyes, a mouth lined with mandibles, and a pair of feathery antennae complete their alien appearance.

Because of their hostile homeworld, skathári are well adapted to extremes, bearing scorching heat, deathly cold, and poisonous atmospheres with ease. Moreover, they can rapidly regenerate severed body parts, regrowing entire limbs in the course of a day. These traits have made them well-suited to live on practically any world.

entries.name: Skathári Customs
entries: A strict set of rules and customs governs skathári society and guide their everyday lives. Though traditions vary, each skathári clan holds one more or more taboos, that, when broken, are grounds for severe punishment, including exile from the clan. The Skathári Taboos table below can serve as an inspiration for a particular clan's taboo.

entries.caption: Skathári Taboos
rows: The practice of arcane magic is forbidden.
Consuming a particular food is forbidden.
When resting, you must always recite a specific prayer and sleep in a certain orientation.
You must use every part of an animal you kill.
You must always address those of higher social status by their full names and titles.
You cannot own more than you can carry.
You cannot bathe, or you can only bathe on certain days.
You are honor-bound to accept any challenge to single combat.

entries.name: Technophobic
entries: Perhaps the only universal taboo held by skathári is a deep and unabiding mistrust of all technology, magical and nonmagical alike. Many skathári warriors would fight unarmed with their claws and mandibles, rather than raise a blaster or laser sword in their defense. Even technology as simple as windmills earns their ire. This taboo stems from a general skepticism of anything too complicated to understand at a glance, and extends to most forms of magic. Skathári especially regard conjuration, illusion, and enchantment magic as they do most technology: with skepticism and occasionally fear.

Though most skathári are loath to ride in spacecraft for any reason, a few grin and bear it (generally clinging to the floor for the duration of the flight). Commonly, traveling skathári try to ignore most technology, and even pretend that constructs, including vect, simply aren't there. And with these occasional hops across the inky blackness of space, skathári have steadily expanded on the margins of the galaxy.

A skathári has a single given name, usually passed down from a prominent ancestor. Throughout their lives, skathári also accumulate titles based on their deeds and accomplishments, which they append at the end of their names as honorifics. The oldest and most well-respected skathári typically have gathered a long list which must be recited to greet them with respect.

entries.name: Skathári Names
entries: Bmarsk, Drikt, Fraxas, Ruzkor, Skrath, Turur, Xast, Xebraks

entries.name: Skathári Titles
entries: Bearer of Scars, Dragon-Slayer, Far- Glider, Faster than the Rest, Lifter of Boulders, Master of Swords, Rider of Beasts, Spear-Thrower, Wood-Carver

raceFluff.name: Vect

entries: Very gradually, by degrees, pale blue hues invade the quiet of night, and Hammerer knows that only a few hours remain until dawn. Throughout the afternoon, evening, and night, he has meticulously inspected his tools, a wide array of mallets, sledges, and, of course, hammers, cleaning them, performing repairs, and organizing them by size and by color, only powering down for a few hours in the middle of the night.

Through the walls of his workshop, Hammerer can see the heat signatures of people waking up and preparing breakfast; he performs a similar ritual, polishing his chassis and running diagnostics for the day ahead. Mentally, he has a checklist of duties and chores before he begins the day's work.

Finally, the clocks strike seven, and Hammerer leaves his home, a room barely ten feet square, and heads out into the town. Somewhere in the market, a child cries for his mother to buy him a toy, and Hammerer puzzles at this behavior; work, after all, is far more interesting than frivolity.
entries.by: A typical morning for Hammerer, a vect craftsman

entries: Living constructs designed as laborers, the vect are now free to search the 'Verse for meaning.

entries.name: Evolved Golems
entries: The vect were preceded by unthinking golems of various designs; however, unlike their forerunners, vect are fully living beings. Underneath their armored exteriors lies an organically-influenced anatomy, with a circulatory system and a network of magical nerves. At the heart of each vect unit is an everlasting construct core, tinged with the influence of the Spark that awoke them.

Vect bodies are humanoid in shape, but unmistakably mechanical, with large air intakes, protective shoulder plates, toothless jaws, and glowing mechanical eyes. They share a general profile, and vary somewhat in proportions, but never so much that their components are incompatible with one another. In fact, many vect choose to install specially-designed upgrades to their bodies, replacing arms or legs with such tools. When a vect readies for a journey, their preparation may include purchasing spare limbs in case things go awry.

Vect work tirelessly and never require sleep, instead entering a dreamless period of inactivation each day. It isn't uncommon to see a vect standing watch over their party, sharpening tools and repairing armor while the others sleep.

entries.name: Mechanical Minds
entries: Although vect experience fear, anger, pain, loss, and other emotions as other humanoids, their expression is muted. Their mechanical features leave little room for nuance, driving an emotional wedge between vect and other living things. Some vect embracethis mechanical nature and seek refuge in logical reasoning, whereas others plumb the philosophies of existence and consider what it means to be alive. These are the two extremes of vect personalities, but most exist between the two.
Vect are most comfortable existing within a small group of some kind, as long as it is dedicated to a purpose. Temples, adventuring parties, and voyages of exploration make for attractive prospects.

entries.name: Search for Meaning
entries: All vect are keenly aware that they were once unliving material imbued suddenly with life. And while there is no doubt that vect are alive, the philosophical implications are staggering: From whence do their souls originate? Where does a vect's soul go when they die? These questions echo loudly inside some vect.

Though the Foundry ship that builds vect is intelligent beyond measure, it ascribes no grand meaning to its creations. The enigmatic ship simply creates vect and drops them, seemingly at random, into the 'Verse.

Some vect find comfort in faith, worshiping gods of arcana, smiths, and machines. Others seek permanent distraction in quests and chores. Others still search the 'Verse for answers in the hopes of finding some profound answer to life.

entries.name: Vect Names
entries: The original vect were divided into working groups and given numbers by their dwarven keepers; nothing more was necessary. Now, however, all vect choose their own names, usually designations reflecting some function or purpose, though some vect choose to be identified by their serial number, or a nickname given to them by others.

entries.name: Vect Names
entries: 176, Armory, Bolts, Clunk, Crusher, Glitch, Hammerer, Keeper, Lifter, Null, Phong, Scarce, Titan, Unit Seventeen, Watcher

raceFluff.name: Wrothian

entries: And what did Alice and Bobby see coming out of the spaceship? Was it the blobby Amoeboids?
No!” the eager group of children responded in unison.
Was it the silly Bird-People?
No!” the children repeated.
Was it the beepy-boopy Vect?
No!” the children cried, sensing the end of storytime.
No, it was the scary Wrothian! the teacher grimaced and growled, It grinned with its sharp teeth and grabbed Alice and Bobby with its pointy nails!

When most spacers are young, they hear a bedtime story about the wroth: fearsome invaders from beyond the stars that come by night to steal away bad little girls and boys. When they grow up, however, they learn that the truth is far more terrible.

The dreaded wroth perhaps originate in deep space, for that is where they reside: in the nothingness between worlds. They are a blight on the galaxy, arriving by night upon defenseless worlds, abducting people with their machines and slaughtering anyone that resists. When they are satisfied with their cruelty, they retreat with their captives, who are never to be seen again.

The very word "wroth" can spark panic on Frontier worlds, where defenses are few and far between, but the wroth prey everywhere. Wrothian ships descend equally on worlds in the galactic core and on the uttermost edge of the 'Verse. As such, they are universally feared and despised.

entries.name: Imperfect Rogue
entries: Most consider wrothians to be avowedly evil, a scourge of the Galactic Frontier; but by some providence, you were born different. Like all wrothian takers, you were created imperfect, using a fraction of the biomatter allotted to the unholy primarchs. These primarchs rule over your kind, psionically commanding you to go to the small, pale worlds below and harvest their people.

Perhaps you were exiled from your ship for demonstrating some act of mercy, or perhaps you escaped to free yourself from the oppressive primarch regime. Regardless, you are now a Rogue, an enemy of all wrothians and feared by all others.

In abandoning your life with the wroth, you have also forsaken your immortality. Without the sustenance of psionic energy found on wrothian ships, your body will deteriorate and perish in less than a decade. Perhaps this death will be a mercy, or perhaps you will seek some darker alternative to death's oblivion. Your life's objective is your own, however, no longer dictated by the primarchs.

entries.name: Few Friends, Many Enemies
entries: As a wrothian, you have no bastion to call home and no natural allies in the 'Verse. It is even possible that your former brethren hunt you wherever you go.

You might find company among mercenaries and adventuring parties that value your skills. Spacers tend to be wary around wrothians, but especially on the Galactic Frontier, a wrothian might be able to earn a crew's trust, provided they can prove their worth.
Most rogue wrothians, however, use disguises of a magical caliber. Even a simple {@spell disguise self|XPHB} spell can allow a wrothian to masquerade as a nautilid or skathári for a time.

entries.name: Wrothian Names
entries: Names aren't bestowed on wrothians when they are created; under the primarchs, they have silent, psionic designations that resemble numbers. Rogue wrothians, however, choose their own names when they break free. These names tend to sound intricate, borrowing sounds from the Wrothian language, but carry great personal meaning.

entries.name: Wrothian Names
entries: Ax'omn, Bael'deldist, Falct'maelom, Hry'steriost, Knu'crikolp, Saluh'ark, Tas'garnaacta, Troh'gelt, Vaek'lenthar, Xrau'tsidea, Zred'rrirc

raceFluff.name: Near-Human
entries: Humans are known for being ambitious, diverse, and extremely short-lived, but also have the dubious honor of having an abundance of near-human offshoots, for it seems humans can breed with just about anything. Near-humans are still basically humans, bearing subtly different traits from a wide variety of sources, and are individually rare but make up a surprisingly large portion of any human population.

baseitem.name: Antimatter Dagger
entries: A commonplace handle that produces a fixed length blade of crackling energy. With some skill, this weapon can be hidden up a sleeve, stashed in a belt, or thrown across the room for a precision kill.

baseitem.name: Ballistic Glove
entries: This glove features a cylindrical grip in the palm which strengthens the fists and charges a set of knuckle-mounted force cells. On a strike, the gloves magnify kinetic energy and issue a deafening crack.

baseitem.name: Skathári Warclub
entries: True to their nature, skathári warriors prefer simple, straightforward weapons, such as their traditional warclubs. These clubs are lined with a row of spikes for punching through invertebrate shells and discouraging huge predators.

baseitem.name: Star Hammer
entries: From a sphere mounted at the end of its handle, the star hammer emits a half-dozen radiant jets, appearing like spikes or candle flames. The force through these jets sounds like a gong on particularly hard impacts.

baseitem.name: Utility Axe
entries: This lightweight, folding multitool, popular with Frontier spacers, can chop wood, shred leafy foliage, hammer nails, and open cans. By design, it also serves as a lethal self-defense weapon.

baseitem.name: Wrenchinator
entries: Though different models exist, the most common ship maintenance wrench by far is the Wrenchinator 9000, a tool used by starship mechanics the 'verse over. This incredible oversized wrench can fasten bolts, loosen bolts, and clobber people over the head.

baseitem.name: Hardlight Dart
entries: Glowing in scintillating hardlight, the Hardlight Dart is a magical projectile that shatters and radiates away seconds after impacting its target. Such darts are inexpensive and disposable, favored by assassins.

baseitem.name: Arc Baton
entries: The weighted end of this steel baton contains a trio of crackling electrodes which send a surge of electricity through any creature they touch.

baseitem.name: Battlefist
entries: A mechanical, articulating gauntlet, this weapon slips over a hand and mimics its movements. A Battlefist can deliver crushing blows on its own, but is usually paired with another weapon, such as a blaster, to be employed when enemies draw too near. This weapon is especially favored by the vect, who can integrate one in place of a hand to ensure a weapon is always nearby.

baseitem.name: Laser Claws
entries: When activated, this glove projects dazzling, razor-sharp claws from the fingertips, which can be used to shred a foe to ribbons. Usually, this weapon is wielded in pairs, making a light complement for deft two-weapon fighters.

baseitem.name: Laser Sword
entries: An elegant weapon for a more enlightened age, the Laser Sword which projects a fixed-length laser from a metal hilt when activated. Its weightless blade makes for an agile weapon, capable of slicing through many materials. It could even stop a blaster bolt, but alas, one would need superhuman reflexes to intercept incoming plasma.

baseitem.name: Laser Greatsword
entries: The laser greatsword's two-handed hilt projects the longest fixed laser blade possible, which hisses and mists plasma in its wake. Naturally, this weapon leverages raw force more than agility, and can cleave any foe it catches in half.

baseitem.name: Photonic Lash
entries: A wicked weapon favored by elves, the photonic lash produces a bright tendril of energy from its metal hilt. The lash leaves painful, burning lacerations and lasting scars—a tell-tale sign that one has defied the whims of the Elven Empire.

baseitem.name: Plasma Cutter
entries: Few things are as intimidating as a plasma cutter's circular, white-hot blade. Even when used for its intended purpose, slicing through high-density metal plates, a careless operator might lose fingers or limbs. When used with lethal intent, however, it can cleanly dissect a foe from end to end.

baseitem.name: Repulsor Mace
entries: Force cells stud the head of this mace like the lines of a globe. When swung, the cells energize and magnify the blow with layers of concussive force fields.

baseitem.name: Riveter
entries: Designed to drive foot-long rivets deep into ship hulls, a riveter is amply dangerous even without a rivet inserted. A squeeze of the handle emits a ka-chunk and a retracting bolt that punches through anything or anyone at which it is directed.

baseitem.name: Rocket Hammer
entries: Only the dwarves would conceive of a weapon so unwieldy as the rocket hammer. As its name implies, it is very much a conventional warhammer with a rocket thruster built into the head to magnify its bludgeoning potential.

baseitem.name: Thermal Lance
entries: When a button on this metal tube is pressed, a persistent, foot-long blue stream of flame erupts from its end, scorching those it touches. Though this tool was fashioned for mining asteroids for precious minerals, it has become a favorite (albeit eccentric) choice of weapon for avia-ra warriors.

baseitem.name: Void Needle
entries: The void needle resembles a short fencing foil, with a few obvious discrepancies: its blade is a hyper thin strand of antimatter, a black line enveloped in a mist of plasma that emits a high pitched squeal when activated. It also lacks an obvious handguard, choosing instead an easily concealed profile favored by rogues and assassins.

baseitem.name: Antimatter Pistol
entries: A compact, antimatter-firing companion to the {@item Antimatter Carbine|DarkMatter24}, the {@item Antimatter Pistol|DarkMatter24} is an essential close-quarters backup.

baseitem.name: Avia-Ra Sunstaff
entries: This long staff, forked at its end near a prominent gemstone, is a blaster in its own right. When used in expert hands, the Sunstaff can bludgeon, trip, and strike foes as a {@item Quarterstaff|XPHB}, only to be squeezed in both hands to fire a burst of hot plasma.

baseitem.name: Bolt Caster
entries: An early but reliable blaster design that resembles a crossbow, the Bolt Caster issues single shots of plasma with a long cooldown between shots.

baseitem.name: Ion Cannon
entries: The Ion Cannon fires a bright, diffuse cone, rendering it deadly up close. Between shots, it makes a quiet zipping noise, as the arcane battery charges the ion cell for another blast.

baseitem.name: Phaser
entries: Phasers aren't designed for effectiveness so much as portability and non-lethality. These blasters are often issued to peace-keepers and emissaries that require personal defense but have no intent to kill.

baseitem.name: Standard Carbine
entries: As its name might suggest, the Standard Carbine is the standard-issue blaster for all Hegemony and Coalition troops, which makes it one of the most pervasive weapons in the 'Verse. Spacers of all stripes employ it for its compact size and superb accuracy.

baseitem.name: Antimatter Carbine
entries: A more lethal model of the {@item Standard Carbine|DarkMatter24}, this rifle can automatically fire bolts of antimatter with surprising accuracy.

baseitem.name: Blitz Cannon
entries: With its imposing rectangular muzzle, this brutalist weapon has a clear right and wrong end. Pulling its trigger unleashes a torrent of lightning bolts in a wide, imprecise spray, making it extremely dangerous at point-blank range.

baseitem.name: Concussion Rifle
entries: A series of arcane capacitors run the length of this rifle, terminating in a thick condenser that compresses its blast into a precise burst. A Concussion Rifle is especially deadly at long ranges, and its damage bypasses most energetically-resistant armor.

baseitem.name: Dueling Laser
entries: A pistol intended for honorable, one-on-one duels, the Dueling Laser fires a blinding streak of light and promptly overheats. Spacers favor a Dueling Laser in their offhand for an infrequent but powerful retort.

baseitem.name: Magnus
entries: This impressive handgun weighs almost twice that of a Repeater. Its infamous heft, recoil, and stopping power make it a favorite of spacers that accept no compromises.

baseitem.name: Plasma Launcher
entries: This short tube launches an orb of superheated plasma in an arc. On contact, the ball of plasma pops like a balloon, exploding in a dazzling fireball of sparks.

baseitem.name: REC Gun
entries: The Revolving Exothermic Cannon (or REC gun, for short) operates on the same principle as a conventional blaster, with an arcane battery hooked up to an aperture barrel and so forth, but mounts several blasters on a revolving cylinder and fires each in rapid succession. A tripod mount keeps the blaster stable despite its heft and shocking recoil.

baseitem.name: Repeater
entries: The quintessential handheld blaster, the Repeater is a staple on the Galactic Frontier. Solid, reliable, and packing just enough firepower to bring down an assailant, nearly every explorer worth their salt has one of these blasters strapped to their hip.

baseitem.name: Swarm Pistol
entries: This handheld blaster, styled much like a {@item Repeater|DarkMatter24}, has a wickedly fast automatic fire, capable of spewing dozens of rays in seconds. Dexterous users might even find it possible to use one in each hand for a dazzling spectacle of plasma bolts.
Passed from generation to generation, this blade remembers each master who has wielded it. When you roll a 1 on an attack roll using this weapon, you can reroll and must use the new roll.

entries.name: Upgraded Magic Item
entries: This weapon grows in power as you do. When you reach character level 5, you gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This bonus increases by +1 at level 11 (+2) and level 17 (+3).

entries.name: Ancestral Property
entries: When you find the sword, it has a property determined by the wielder that carried it previously. The GM chooses the sword's property or determines it randomly.

rows: {@b Blindsight.} While attuned to the sword, you have {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} with a range of 20 feet.

{@b Communion.} You can spend 10 minutes communing with the spirits of the sword's previous wielders. Choose the {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Data|DarkMatter24}, {@skill History|XPHB}, {@skill Investigation|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}, {@skill Religion|XPHB}, or {@skill Technology|DarkMatter24} skill. If you lack proficiency in the chosen skill, you gain proficiency in it, and if you already have proficiency in it, you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in it.

{@b Covert.} When you are hidden and a creature discovers you with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, you can take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action as a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to quickly conceal yourself. If your Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) roll beats the creature's Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, you silently reposition yourself and the creature doesn't notice you. Once you use this property, you can't use it again until the next dawn.
{@b Fast Movement.} While attuned to the sword, your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 10 feet.

{@b Returning.} While you are attuned to the sword, it has the {@itemProperty Thrown|XPHB} (Range 40/120) property. You can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to call the sword to you if it is within 60 feet of you and isn't being carried, causing it to fly into your open hand.

{@b Telepathy.} You can speak telepathically to any creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself. Your telepathic utterances are in a language you know, and the creature understands you only if it knows that language. Your communication doesn't give the creature the ability to respond to you telepathically.

entries: While you are holding this magic weapon, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your spells. You gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls using this weapon, to your spell attack rolls, and to the saving throw DCs of your spells as determined by the weapon's rarity.

While you are holding this magic weapon, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your spells. You gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls using this weapon, to your spell attack rolls, and to the saving throw DCs of your spells as determined by the weapon's rarity.

While you are holding this magic weapon, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your spells. You gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls using this weapon, to your spell attack rolls, and to the saving throw DCs of your spells as determined by the weapon's rarity.

This traditional skathári axe is carved from rough-hewn ironwood. When you score a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB} with the axe, you regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the slashing damage dealt.

entries.name: Upgraded Magic Item
entries: This weapon grows in power as you do. When you reach character level 5, you gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This bonus increases by +1 at level 11 (+2) and level 17 (+3).

While attuned to this magic weapon, you have proficiency in it and can use its mastery property, even if you don't have the Weapon Mastery feature, and it doesn't count against the number of weapons you can use. This weapon has 3 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn. When you miss a ranged attack made with this blaster, you can expend 1 charge to gain a +5 bonus to the attack roll, potentially causing the attack to hit. A built-in AI within this blaster congratulates you when you hit an enemy, and condescendingly berates you when you miss.

This shimmering armor shifts its color to match its surroundings. If you move 15 feet or less on your turn while wearing the suit, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check you make as part of the {@action Hide|XPHB} action. Additionally, you can take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action while you're {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

This armored suit is traced in intricate, glowing attachment points across its surface. You can install construct grafts into this suit, which has four body slots: Arms, External, Head, and Legs. While wearing this armor, you gain the benefits of any construct grafts installed in the suit, though you lose the benefits of any grafts you have attached to your own body (except those in the Internal slot).
You can don and doff this armor as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When this weapon hits a ship or a creature of Mega size, it deals 1 Mega {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} of damage.

This skin-tight suit shifts your body out of phase with the Material Plane. While attuned to it, you can move solid objects and occupied spaces as if they were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. If you end your turn in such a space, you are shunted to the last unoccupied space you were in.

This magical blaster has a revolving set of five power cells. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can change the blaster's damage type to Cold, Fire, Lightning, Necrotic, or Radiant damage. This blaster deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the chosen type to any target it hits.

item.name: Bandolier
entries: This shoulder strap contains six pouches large enough to hold a potion, grenade, or similarly-sized item within easy reach. It can hold 10 pounds of gear.

item.name: Binoculars
entries: Objects viewed through Binoculars are magnified to ten times their size.

item.name: Comm Set
entries: Using this handheld device, you can verbally communicate with any creature within 1 mile that also has a Comm Set. A Comm Set can be connected to a headset worn on the ear or can be talked into directly. Its signal can penetrate most barriers, but is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

item.name: Engineer's Pack
entries: An Engineer's Pack includes a {@item Backpack|XPHB}, a {@item Comm Set|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Crowbar|XPHB}, a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24}, a Hammer, an {@item Igniter|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}, dozens of assorted nuts and bolts, an {@item Omnitool|DarkMatter24}, 10 rolls of {@item Vent Tape|DarkMatter24}, and a {@item Wristwatch|DarkMatter24}.

item.name: Flare
entries: A Flare is a foot-long, brightly colored stick with a plastic cap. You can strike the bottom of the Flare as a Utilize action, causing it to burst into a bright, colored flame, matching that of the stick. This flame burns for 10 minutes, emitting a 40-foot radius of {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 20 feet. A Flare can burn underwater and in a vacuum.

item.name: Flashlight
entries: A Flashlight produces a 60-foot cone of {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}, and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 15 feet. It can provide light for up to 4 hours, after which it must recharge for 8 hours.

item.name: Holster
entries: A Holster is a specially-made holder which allows a blaster which lacks {@itemProperty 2H|XPHB|Two-Handed} to be carried on a belt or under the arm.

item.name: Hypodermic Needle
entries: Potions are often loaded into syringes instead of consumed from a bottle. You can load a potion into a Hypodermic Needle as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} and administer it to another creature as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. If the creature is unwilling, it must succeed a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 plus your Intelligence modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) to avoid the needle.

item.name: Igniter
entries: An Igniter produces a small flame, which you can use to light a Candle, Torch, or campfire.

item.name: Interface Rig
entries: An Interface Rig includes everything necessary to connect to a device without an accessible interface: a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24} accessor loaded with complicated algorithms, a plethora of wires and connectors, and a heavy magnet in case things get dire. An Interface Rig is often necessary to gain unauthorized access to a system.

item.name: Krash
entries: When you drink this can of sugary liquid as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, you feel a rush of energy. For the next hour, your {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level temporarily decreases by 1, to a minimum of 0. You can only be under the effect of one can of Krash at a time.

item.name: Log Keeper
entries: This foot-long device records and replays audio, organizing entries by date. It can store up to 72 hours of audio before it automatically begins purging the earliest entries.

item.name: Marine's Pack
entries: A Marine's Pack includes a {@item Backpack|XPHB}, a {@item Bedroll|XPHB}, {@item Binoculars|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Comm Set|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Concussion Grenade|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Crowbar|XPHB}, a {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Igniter|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}, 10 days of {@item Rations|XPHB}, {@item Rope|XPHB}, a {@item Tactical Vest|DarkMatter24}, and a roll of {@item Vent Tape|DarkMatter24}.

item.name: Omnitool
entries: This multipurpose gadget contains a plethora of useful tools: small knives of various sizes, a small hammer, screwdrivers, a file, a bottle opener, a small saw, a wrench, a can opener, a wire-cutter, and a small set of pliers.

item.name: Quadcorder
entries: This handheld scanning device has four prominent sensors (each looking like a small radar dish) on its operating end. When directed at an object within 5 feet as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, the device measures and displays many of that object's intrinsic properties, including its temperature, density, boiling point, freezing point, conductivity, and viscosity.

item.name: Researcher's Pack
entries: A Researcher's Pack includes a {@item Backpack|XPHB}, {@item Binoculars|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Comm Set|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Holo-Sphere|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Hypodermic Needle|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Log Keeper|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Omnitool|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Quadcorder|DarkMatter24}, and a {@item Wristwatch|DarkMatter24}.

item.name: Roach
entries: Ocoulori Radavitis (called a Roach by many spacers) is an insectlike creature that is consumed to improve the results of a void jump. See the Ships chapter for more details.

item.name: Sling
entries: A Sling is a strap which attaches to a weapon (usually a blaster) and is worn on the body. When you drop a weapon attached to a sling you are wearing, it falls to your side and continues to hang within reach.

item.name: Spacer's Pack
entries: A Spacer's Pack includes a {@item Backpack|XPHB}, a {@item Bandolier|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Comm Set|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24}, 2 {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24|Flashlights}, a {@item Holo-Sphere|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Interface Rig|DarkMatter24}, 2 cans of {@item Krash|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Log Keeper|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Igniter|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Omnitool|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Quadcorder|DarkMatter24}, 10 rolls of {@item Vent Tape|DarkMatter24}, and a {@item Wristwatch|DarkMatter24}.

item.name: Surveyor's Pack
entries: A Surveyor's Pack includes a {@item Backpack|XPHB}, a {@item Bandolier|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Bedroll|XPHB}, {@item Binoculars|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Comm Set|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Log Keeper|DarkMatter24}, an {@item Igniter|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Life Suit|DarkMatter24}, a {@item Quadcorder|DarkMatter24}, 10 days of {@item Rations|XPHB}, {@item Rope|XPHB}, and a {@item Wristwatch|DarkMatter24}.

item.name: Tactical Vest
entries: This light vest is covered in pouches, straps, and holsters. The vest can carry a Melee weapon with the Two-Handed or Versatile property on its back and a Dagger or an Antimatter Dagger on its front. It has two Holsters and one built-in Sling. The Tactical Vest can be worn atop armor.

item.name: Vent Tape
entries: This durable, adhesive tape is useful for any application that involves sticking two things together. While more creative minds might use large quantities of Vent Tape for other uses, most people use it for quick repairs and affixed {@item Flashlight|DarkMatter24|Flashlights} to blasters in a pinch. A single roll of Vent Tape contains 60 feet of 2-inch wide tape.

item.name: Wristwatch
entries: A simple device with a simple purpose, this watch reports the time in a way that is consistent with all major galactic factions.

item.name: Attractor Mine
entries: This small metallic disk hums with gravitational energy. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with throwing the mine to a space you can see within 30 feet of you. The mine firmly attaches to any surface it touches. If a creature other than you enters the 5-foot Cube area originating at the top of the mine or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or have its Speed reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn. After 10 minutes, the mine burns out and becomes nonmagical.

item.name: Ankh of Ra
entries: This golden holy symbol, blessed by the Sun Above, shields you from death. If you drop to 0 Hit Points while you wear this ankh, roll {@dice 4d10}. Your Hit Points instead change to the number rolled. The ankh then loses its luster and becomes nonmagical.

entries.name: Magic Item Set
entries: Attuning to this ankh and a {@item Heretical Sunstaff of Ra|DarkMatter24} and {@item Solar Wings of Ra|DarkMatter24} counts as being attuned to a single item. If you are attuned to this ankh and one of these items, the ankh doesn't become nonmagical once used. Instead, it temporarily loses its luster and can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Arcane Terminal
entries: Arcane Terminals are essential units of computing in the 'Verse. Most information, from private financial records to a ship's star charts, are stored on such terminals. These terminals weigh 500 pounds and come equipped with a keyboard and monitor.

entries.name: Data Storage
entries: A terminal can store arbitrarily large amounts of data, including text, images, and video. Authorized users can search the terminal's data and the data of any other terminal connected to it as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action. Typically, Arcane Terminals on populated worlds are connected together in planetary networks ("nets") which allow a user to comb through a vast, encyclopedic collection of knowledge, whereas individual terminals are more focused and may only contain information on a few topics.

entries.name: Communication Network.
entries: If the terminal has an installed antenna, authorized users can interface with it using a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24} out to a range of 1 mile. Multiple users can communicate with each other within that range, using text, audio, or video.

entries.name: Ship Computers and Other Functions.
entries: Starships generally have an Arcane Terminal aboard to control its sensors and systems. These terminals can also perform tasks such as opening and closing doors of a facility, issuing commands to Constructs, or processing technical data.

entries.name: Hacking
entries: Each terminal generally restricts access to authorized users. A DC 15 Intelligence (Data) check can hack a terminal and provide unauthorized access. More secure systems might have higher DCs for this check. See "Intelligence (Data)" in the Glossary for the rules on Hacking.

item.name: Arcane Warhead
entries: This 4,000-pound bomb is capable of cataclysmic destruction.

entries.name: Arming the Warhead
entries: You can arm the warhead over the course of a minute if you know the warhead's command code and have a specially-made key attuned to it. Once the warhead is armed, you can set its method of detonation: Timed or Impact. If you choose a timed detonation, you enter a delay time of 1 minute, 10 minutes, or 1 hour, after which the warhead detonates. If you choose impact, the bomb lays dormant until it is reduced to 0 Hit Points. The warhead has AC 18, 100 Hit Points (1 Mega Hit Point), and immunity to Poison and Psychic damage.

entries.name: Detonation
entries: When the warhead detonates, most things nearby are instantly vaporized. Within a 10-mile-radius Sphere, each creature and object takes {@dice 10d10 + 200} Mega Radiant damage. Each creature outside of the 10-mile-radius Sphere but within a 100-mile-radius Sphere makes a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 10d10 + 50} Radiant damage, or half as much on a successful save. This damage ignores Resistance and Immunity. A creature that takes damage from this warhead has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 24 hours.
The epicenter of the blast becomes a spherical Dead Magic Zone, ranging from a few dozen feet to several miles in diameter.

item.name: Ballistic Sledge
entries: Once on each of your turns, when you make a melee attack with this weapon, you can engage its thrusters to strike with extra force. You can lunge up to 15 feet toward your target before making the attack. Doing so doesn't spend movement or provoke Opportunity Attacks. On a hit, the attack deals an extra {@damage 1d4} Bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Upgraded Magic Item
entries: This weapon grows in power as you do. When you reach character level 5, you gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This bonus increases by +1 at level 11 (+2) and level 17 (+3).

entries.name: The B
entries: E.G.—short for "Big Effing Gun"—is an experimental weapon of unrivaled power. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can activate this weapon, creating an explosion of lightning and plasma in a 30-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on a point you can see within 120 feet. Each creature in the area must succeed on a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 10d10 + 50} Radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Once you use this item, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Blaster Prototype
entries: Every blaster in the 'Verse, from pocket-sized Phasers to ship-mounted Pulse Cannons, operate on the same basic principle: focusing the energy from an arcane battery through an aperture to create an burst of radiation. However, the progenitor to all blasters predates the invention of arcane batteries, and instead utilized a more potent power source: a mortal soul.

The Blaster Prototype was the magnum opus of legendary dwarven inventor Metzer Glimwrought. As the device neared its completion, Metzer's daughter, Vantha Glimwrought, suddenly took ill and deteriorated quickly. Doctors could furnish no cure and Metzer, desperate, turned to necromancy. Using the ritual that binds a lich's phylactery, Metzer bound his daughter's soul to the prototype, simultaneously forestalling her death and furnishing the blaster with an immense power source.

entries.name: Magic Weapon
entries: The Blaster Prototype is a magic weapon that grants a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it.

entries.name: Auto-Aim
entries: If you roll less than 10 on the {@dice d20} for an attack roll with the Blaster Prototype, you can replace the roll with a 10. The prototype can choose not to grant this benefit, or to instead replace the roll with a 1 if it believes a target is unsuitable.

entries.name: Blaster Mastery
entries: You can use a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to change the blaster's mastery property to that of any blaster of your choice. You can use the mastery property of the blaster, even if you don't have the Weapon Mastery feature, and it doesn't count against the number of weapons you can use. Once you change the mastery property, you can't do so again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Machine Code
entries: Using its Machine Code language, the Blaster Prototype can cast the Technomancy cantrip.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: The Blaster Prototype is a sentient Chaotic Neutral weapon with an Intelligence of 16, a Wisdom of 10, and a Charisma of 15. It has hearing and {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} out to 120 feet.
The prototype speaks Common, Dwarven, and Machine Code, the native code-language of machines, and it can communicate with its wielder telepathically.

entries.name: Personality
entries: Though the prototype is ageless, its personality belongs to a young woman, Vantha Glimwrought, and speaks in an upbeat, chipper tone. The Prototype urges its user to travel to new places and meet interesting people; likewise, it hates being holstered, hidden away, or ignored. Even in life, Vantha was shut away and built up an insatiable wanderlust.

Vantha has complex feelings about her father, the prototype's inventor. Without question, she's grateful to be alive, but feels like her present, captive circumstances are somehow an extension of her father's overbearing nature, even after his death.
Vantha has reservations about being used on Humanoids and will never fire on a person she deems innocent.

entries.name: Destroying the Blaster
entries: The Blaster Prototype is protected by all manner of enchantments from one of history's most ingenious arcanists, rendering it impervious to damage. However, if the blaster is connected to a sufficiently large power source, like a Class 7 or 8 Dark Matter engine at the moment of a void jump, the power surge would be enough to overload the blaster and destroy it.

item.name: Bottled Lightning
entries: A bolt of magic lightning surges around inside this glass canister, casting {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 10-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 10 feet.

When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with throwing the Bottled Lightning. Target one creature or object you can see within 20 feet of yourself. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) or take {@damage 2d8} Lightning damage and be unable to make Opportunity Attacks until the start of its next turn.

item.name: Bounty Hunter's Carbine
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

entries.name: Tracker
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack using the carbine, you can mark the target for 24 hours. While the creature is marked and it and the blaster are on the same plane of existence, the blaster beeps intermittently to indicate the target's distance to you. This mark ends if the creature dies or you mark a different creature.

entries.name: Nonlethal
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} using this weapon, you can instead knock the target out, as you would with a Melee weapon.

entries.name: Magic Item Set
entries: If you are carrying this carbine and wearing a {@item Bounty Hunter's Vest|DarkMatter24}, you can disarm your target with a well-placed shot. When you hit a creature with an attack using the carbine and exceed the target's AC by 5 or more or score a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, the target makes a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it drops an object of your choice that it's holding, which lands at its feet.

item.name: Potion of Liquid Air
entries: When you drink this potion, you can breathe underwater or in the vacuum of space for 8 hours. The potion also protects you from extreme temperatures and pressures.

item.name: Potion of Solar Radiance
entries: When you drink this potion, your body casts {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 20-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 20 feet for the next hour. The light is sunlight. Until this duration ends, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on your turn to deal {@damage 1d8} Radiant damage to each creature within the {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}. Its liquid is an opaque silver and glows brightly when shaken.

item.name: Cryogenic Pod
entries: This capsule, large enough to fit one Medium or smaller creature, can provide air and heat for its occupant indefinitely. A creature inside the pod can set a duration ranging from one month to 1,000 years and activate the pod as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action. The pod then locks and cryogenically freezes the creature and the rest of the pod's contents over the course of a minute. A frozen creature has the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition, doesn't age, and doesn't need air, food, or water. When the duration expires, the pod deactivates, thawing the creature and the pod's contents over the course of a minute. The pod then unlocks.
If a creature fails to set a duration on the pod, it remains frozen until another creature takes a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to deactivate and unlock the pod.

item.name: Data Drive
entries: This 1-inch long drive can store arbitrarily large amounts of data, including text, images, and video. Over the course of a minute, you can transfer information between a Data Drive and an Arcane Terminal, {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24}, or similar computer. You can only upload or download information you have access to; certain information may be encrypted and be accessible only to authorized users. Information stored on a Data Drive can't be directly read without a device like a {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24} that has an interface.

item.name: Datapad
entries: This flat, rectangular device can perform countless personal computing tasks. For example, a Datapad can take text notes, view downloaded data, transfer credits to and from the Galactic Bank, and interface with other devices.

Datapads can interface with one another and Arcane Terminals within a range of 1 mile. Users can communicate with each other using text, audio, or video, and search the contents of any connected Arcane Terminal. Typically, Arcane Terminals on populated worlds are connected together in planetary networks ("nets") which allow a user to comb through a vast, encyclopedic collection of knowledge and provide connection between any two users across the planet.

item.name: Diode Beam
entries: This two-handed beam weapon has 3 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can expend 1 charge to replace one of your attacks with a 5-foot-wide, 60-foot-long {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} in a direction you choose. Each creature in the {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} makes a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d8} Radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Upgraded Magic Item
entries: If you have proficiency in Martial weapons, this item grows in power as you do. The item's save DC increases when you reach level 5 (DC 15), 11 (DC 17), and 17 (DC 18).

item.name: Dome Projector
entries: Activating this egg-shaped device as an action creates a dome of force centered on the projector as if you had cast the Geodesic {@spell Shield|XPHB} spell. When the spell ends, the projector burns out and becomes nonmagical.

item.name: Drive Wheel
entries: By grasping the two handles on this foot-wide steering wheel, you can cast the {@spell Speedcycle|DarkMatter24} spell. The motorcycle materializes beneath you and attaches to the steering wheel.
Once you use this item to cast the {@spell Speedcycle|DarkMatter24} spell, it can't be used again until the following dawn.

item.name: Encyclopedia Multiplanaria
entries: This {@item Datapad|DarkMatter24} is enchanted to hold an incredible wealth of information. However, the data isn't indexed, so the Encyclopedia only provides data that it believes will be useful at any given moment. The Encyclopedia 3 charges, and regains all charges daily at dawn. When you take the {@action Study|XPHB} action, you can expend 1 charge to access the Encyclopedia and gain a +20 to any Intelligence checks you make as a part of that action.

item.name: Etheradio
entries: An essential tool for galactic communication, an Etheradio transmits and receives its messages though the Ethereal Plane. This device stands over 6 feet tall (with an antenna that extends its length by an additional 3 feet) and weighs 1,000 pounds.

entries.name: Transmitting
entries: An operator can use the device as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to transmit an audio message of up to 10 minutes to a specific Etheradio on the same plane of existence or to an etheradio station. Hundreds of stations exist, many of them earmarked for specific uses, such as streaming music or government communications. By broadcasting on an emergency station, an Etheradio can transmit a message to all other Etheradios on the same plane of existence, but it can only send such a message once per day. No matter the distance, messages take 10 minutes to reach their destination.

entries.name: Receiving
entries: The Etheradio stores the most recent 10 hours of audio it has directly received. An operator can use the device as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to listen to stored audio or to tune into an Etheradio station.

entries.name: Calibration
entries: An Etheradio only works if it is calibrated according to its location in the universe. Calibrating this device takes 1 hour, and it must be recalibrated if it is ever moved more than 100 miles. Calibration takes into account regular cosmic motion, such as a planet's orbit.

item.name: Flamethrower
entries: This two-handed nozzle, connected to a backpack of arcane batteries, has 7 charges and regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn.

When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can replace one or more of your attacks with a 15-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone} of fire from the Flamethrower, expending 1 charge for each attack replaced in this way. Each creature in that area makes a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d6} Fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Upgraded Magic Item
entries: If you have proficiency in Martial weapons, this item grows in power as you do. The item's save DC increases when you reach level 5 (DC 15), 11 (DC 17), and 17 (DC 18).

item.name: Flashback Polaroid
entries: This antique camera is loaded with a roll of film containing {@dice 1d6 + 2} blank photos. You can use a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to take a picture using the camera, casting the Flashback spell. The developed photo depicts the events that the spell has altered. When all of the camera's photos have been taken, it ceases to be magical.

item.name: Gamestation
